revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} This is a list of awards, winners and commendations awarded by the international '''[[World Architecture Festival]]''' (WAF).
==History== In 2008 all winners were award winners. In 2009 and later only 5 of the winners were declared award winners.
The list is compiled from the official websites of World Architecture Festival and World Buildings Directory. Where there was a discrepancy between the information on the project page and the winner list with WAF, the information from the WAF list was used. All names are spelled as in the WAF list, links may therefore lead to articles with different spellings. In some cases the projects were renamed after receiving the award. The notes to the list contain a link to the project page with World Buildings Directory and are sorted in the same sequence as in the winner lists published by the World Architecture Festival. <ref name=win2008>{{Kilde www|tittel=World Architecture Festival winners 2008|url=http://www.worldarchitecturefestival.com/winners.cfm?eventYear=2008|utgiver=World Architecture Festival|besøksdato=2013-07-13|dødlenke=ja|arkivurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730045022/http://www.worldarchitecturefestival.com/winners.cfm?eventYear=2008|arkivdato=30 July 2013}}</ref> <ref name=win2009>{{Kilde www|tittel=World Architecture Festival winners 2009|url=http://www.worldarchitecturefestival.com/winners.cfm?eventYear=2009|utgiver=World Architecture Festival|besøksdato=2013-07-13|dødlenke=ja|arkivurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730053127/http://www.worldarchitecturefestival.com/winners.cfm?eventYear=2009|arkivdato=30 July 2013}}</ref> <ref Festival|besøksdato=2013-07-13|dødlenke=ja|arkivurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130730053822/http://www.worldarchitecturefestival.com/winners.cfm?eventYear=2010|arkivdato=30 July 2013}}</ref> <ref {{Infobox architectural practice |image= Skuespilhuset København.jpg |caption= [[Royal Danish Playhouse]], [[Copenhagen]] |name= Lundgaard & Tranberg Arkitekter |architects= [[Lene Tranberg]] |city = [[Copenhagen]] |founded=1983 |significant_buildings= [[Royal Danish Playhouse]]
[[Tietgenkollegiet]] |awards= 6 [[RIBA European Award]]s |}} '''Lundgaard & Tranberg Arkitekter''' is a Danish [[architecture|architectural firm]], based in [[Copenhagen]] [[Denmark]]. It is most noted for the [[Tietgenkollegiet]] student housing in [[Ørestad]] from 2006 and the [[Royal Danish Playhouse]] on the Copenhagen harbourfront from 2008. Lundgaard & Tranberg has won [[RIBA European Award]]s three years in a row in 2006, 2007 and 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.architecture.com/Awards/RIBAEuropeanAwards/RIBAEuropeanAwards.aspx |title=RIBA European Awards |publisher=RIBA |accessdate=2009-09-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930190836/http://www.architecture.com/Awards/RIBAEuropeanAwards/RIBAEuropeanAwards.aspx |archivedate=2009-09-30 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.e-architect.co.uk/awards/riba_awards_2007.htm|title=RIBA Awards 2007: UK|publisher=e-architects|accessdate=2009-09-21}} ==History== Lundgaard & Tranberg was founded in 1983 by Boje Lundgaard and Lene Tranberg. In the 1990s, the firm gained a reputation as designers of [[Combined heat and power plant|heat & power plant]] and other technical facilities, while its breakthrough in the general public came in the mid-2000s with the Charlottehaven from residential project from 2004 and particularly the award-winning and highly celebrated designs for the Tietgenkollegiet student residences and a new building for the [[Royal Danish Theater]]. In 2004, just when the firm's major success set in, Boje Lundgaard departed, and Lene Tranberg continued the practice with a new partner group. ==Selected buildings== ===Completed=== * Charlottehaven residences, Copenhagen (2004) * [[Tietgenkollegiet]], [[Ørestad]], Copenhagen * Kilen, [[Copenhagen Business School]], [[Frederiksberg]], Copenhagen (2007) * Fyrtårnet residences, Copenhagen (2007) * [[Royal Danish Playhouse]], Copenhagen, (2008) * residential buildings [[Havneholmen]], Copenhagen (2009) * [[Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken|SE Bank]] highrises, Copenhagen (2010) * [[Sorø Art Museum]], [[Sorø]], Denmark (2011) * [[Pier47]], [[Langelinie]], Copenhagen (2014) ===In progress=== * Sustainable office building, [[Langelinie]], Copenhagen (competition win 2009) * Tuborg Syd highrises, Hellerup, Copenhagen * Garden pavilion, [[Louisiana Museum of Modern Art]], [[Humlebæk]], Denmark (competition win, January 2011) * ''Minaret '' monument, [[Muscat, Oman|Muscat]], [[Oman]] (competition win, January 2011){{cite web|url=http://main.omanobserver.om/node/38221|title=Majestic Muscat’ to enhance the quality of living|publisher=Oman Daily Observer|accessdate=2011-02-03}} * Shipyard redevelopment, [[Helsinki]], Finland (competition win, February 2011) * Danish University Centre, [[Beijing]], China (competition win, February 2011) * [[Copenhagen Plant Science Centre]], [[Frederiksberg]] Denmark (competition win, April 2011){{cite web|url=http://www.ubst.dk/publikationer/copenhagen-plant-science-centre-juryens-betenkning/Copenhagen%20Plant%20Science%20Centre%20-%20juryens%20betaenkning.pdf|title=Copenhagen Plant Science Centre|publisher=University of Copenhagen|accessdate=2011-04-11}} ==Awards and recognition== * Boje Lundgaard won the [[Nykredit Architecture Prize]] in 1995{{cite web|title=Nykredit Architecture Prize |url=http://www.nykredit.dk/omnykredit/info/virksomhed/nykredits-arkitekturpris.xml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100220131650/http://www.nykredit.dk/omnykredit/info/virksomhed/nykredits-arkitekturpris.xml |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 February 2010 |work=Nykredit website |publisher=Nykredit Holding A/S |accessdate=30 November 2013 |location=Copenhagen, Denmark |language=Danish |year=2013 }} * Lene Tranberg won the [[Nykredit Architecture Prize]] in 2005 * [[RIBA European Award#2006|2006 RIBA European Award]] for ''Kilen'' * [[RIBA European Award#2007|2007 RIBA European Award]] for ''Tietgenkollegiet'' * [[RIBA European Award#2008|2008 RIBA European Award]] for ''Royal Danish Playhouse'' * [[RIBA European Award#2011|2011 RIBA European Award]] for ''Havneholmen Apartments''{{cite web|url=http://www.architecture.com/Awards/RIBAAwards/Winners2011/EU/Europeanwinners2011.aspx|title=2011 RIBA European Awards|publisher=RIBA|accessdate=2011-05-23|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915014514/http://www.architecture.com/Awards/RIBAAwards/Winners2011/EU/Europeanwinners2011.aspx|archivedate=2012-09-15|df=}} * [[RIBA European Award#2011|2011 RIBA European Award]] for ''SEB Bank'' * [[RIBA European Award|2013 RIBA EU Award]] for ''Sorø Art Museum''{{cite web|url=http://www.architecture.com/NewsAndPress/News/RIBANews/News/2013/2013RIBANationalandEUAwardsannounced.aspx#.Ubu1J9zU-8Q|title=2013 RIBA National and EU Awards announced|publisher=RIBA|accessdate=2013-06-15}} * [[MIPIM|2013 MIPIM Award#MIPIM Awards]] for ''ulture Casbah'' (Best Future Project){{cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/351611/mipim-awards-winners-2013/|title=MIPIM Awards Winners 2013 |publisher=ArchDaily|accessdate=2014-06-21}} ==Gallery== File:Tietgenkollegiet facade.jpg| ''[[Tietgenkollegiet]]'', Copenhagen (2005) File:Vejen til Kilen.jpg|The Wedge, [[Copenhagen Business School]] (2006) File:Fårtårnet, Amerikas Plads.jpg|''Fyrtårnet'', Copenhagen (2007) File:Skuespilhuset-profil.jpg|[[Royal Danish Playhouse]], Copenhagen (2008) Image:Havneholmen housing.jpg|[[Havneholmen]] housing (2009) Image:SEB Bank (Copenhagen).jpg|SEB Bank, Copenhagen Image:Sorø Art Museum - gabled wing.JPG|[[Sorø Art Museum]] Image:Åaljiset )Langelinie=.jpg|Office building, [[Langelinie]], Copenhagen (2014) Image:Axel Towers, Copenhagen.jpg|Axel Towers ==See also== * [[Architecture of Denmark]] * [[List of Danish architectural firms]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Lundgaard & Tranberg}} * [http://www.aplust.net/permalink.php?atajo=lundgaard__tranberg_students_dormitory_copenhagen&filtrado=cat&idioma=en Student's dormitory in Copenhagen. {{coord|38|05|01.10|N|46|18|12.82|E|region:IR|display=title}} [[Image:Maqbaratoshoara 4.JPG|thumb|right|250px|The building of the Mausoleum of Poets.]] [[Image:Maqbaratoshoara05.jpg|thumb|250px|The dome.]] [[Image:Maqbaratoshoara10.jpg|thumb|250px|Grave of [[Mohammad-Hossein Shahriar|Shahryar]].]] '''[[Maqbara|Maqbarat]]-o-shoara''' ({{lang-ar|مقبرةالشعراء}}) or the '''Mausoleum of Poets''' ({{lang|fa|مزارِ شاعران}} ''Mazār-e Shāerān'' or {{lang|fa|مزارِ سرایندگان}} ''Mazār-e Sorāyandegān'') is a graveyard belonging to classical and contemporary poets, mystics and other notable people, located in the [[Surkhab district]] of [[Tabriz]] in [[Iran]]. It was built by Tahmaseb Dolatshahi in the mid-1970s while he was the Secretary of Arts and Cultures of [[East Azarbaijan]].
On the east side of Sayyed Hamzeh's grave and Ghaem Magham's grave, there is a graveyard containing the graves of important poets, mystics, scientists and well-known people of Tabriz. The Mausoleum was first mentioned by the medieval historian [[Hamdollah Mostowfi]] in his ''[[Nozhat ol-Gholub]]''. Hamdollah mentions it being located in what, at the time, was the Surkhab district of Tabriz.
Since the 1970s, there have been attempts to renovate the graveyard area. Some work has been carried out like the construction of a new symbolic building on this site.
The first poet buried in this complex is [[Asadi Tusi]] (999-1072).
== Notable Burials == *[[Asadi Tusi]] (999-1072) - poet *[[Qatran Tabrizi]] (1009-1072) - poet *[[Anvari|Anvari Abivardi]] (1126-1189) - poet *[[Khaqani]] (1122-1190) - poet *[[Mojireddin Bilaqani]] (d. 1190) - poet *[[Zahir-al-Din Faryabi|Zahireddin Faryabi]] (d. 1202) - poet *[[Shapur Nishapuri]] (d. 1204) - poet *[[Shamseddin Sojasi]] (d. 1206) - poet *[[Zu'l-Fiqar Shirvani|Zulfaqar Shirvani]] (d. 1290) - poet *[[Homam-e Tabrizi|Homam Tabrizi]] (1238-1314) - poet *[[Nasrollah Tabib]] (d. 1339) - calligrapher *[[Assar Tabrizi]] (1325-1390) - poet *[[Maghrebi Tabrizi]] (1348-1406) - poet *[[Mani Shirazi]] (d. 1507) - poet *[[Lesani Shirazi]] (d. 1533) - poet *[[Shakibi Tabrizi]] (d. 1564) - poet *[[Mirza Issa Farahani]] (d. 1822) - vizier of [[Fath-Ali Shah]] Qajar and [[Abbas Mirza]] *[[Aziz Khan Mokri]] (d. 1870) - army general *[[Seqat-ol-Eslam Tabrizi|Seqqat ol-Eslam Tabrizi]] (1861-1911) - Persian [[Persian Constitutional Revolution|constitutional]] activist *[[Taher Tabrizi]] (1888-1976) - calligrapher *[[Mohammad-Hossein Shahriar|Mohammad-Hossein Behjat Tabrizi (Shahriar)]] (1906-1988) - poet *[[Mahmoud Melmasi – Azarm|Mahmoud Melmasi (Azarm)]] (1917-1991) - poet *[[Aziz Dowlatabadi|Aziz Dowlatabadi (Darvish)]] (1922-2009) - poet
== See also == * [[Amir Nezam House|The Amir Nezam House]] * [[Behnam House]] * [[House of Seghat ol Islam]] * [[Constitutional House of Tabriz]] * [[Seyed Hamzeh shrine]]

{{Infobox person | name = Maruja Callaved | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Maruja Callaved Gastón | birth_date = {{Birth year|1928}} | birth_place = [[Jaca]], Spain | death_date = {{Death date and given age|2018|01|09|97|df=yes}} | death_place = [[Madrid]], Spain | death_cause = | other_names = | employer = {{Plainlist| * [[Televisión Española]] * [[RTVE]] }} | occupation = Journalist, TV director, presenter | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = | spouse = Antonio Mejía | children = | awards = {{Plainlist| * {{ill|Antena de Oro|es}} (1963) * [[Premios Ondas|Ondas Award]] (1977) }} | alma_mater = [[University of Zaragoza]] }} '''Maruja Callaved''' (1928 – 9 January 2018) was a Spanish television director.<ref name=fallecido>{{Cite news |url=https://www.heraldo.es/noticias/sociedad/2018/01/09/la-periodista-jacetana-maruja-callaved-pionera-informacion-gastronomica-fallecido-madrid-1218086-310.html |title=La periodista jacetana Maruja Callaved, pionera en información gastronómica, ha fallecido en Madrid |trans-title=The Jaca Journalist Maruja Callaved, Pioneer in Gastronomic Information, Has Passed Away in Madrid |first=Laura |last=Zamboraín |work=[[Heraldo de Aragón]] |language=Spanish |date=9 January 2018 |access-date=19 October 2018}}</ref>
==Biography== After settling in [[Zaragoza]], Maruja Callaved studied Philosophy and Literature and graduated in Teaching.
Her professional beginnings were in radio, first at the [[University of Zaragoza]] and later at La Voz de Madrid, although she developed almost all of her professional career at [[Televisión Española]], first as a presenter and later as a director.<ref name=fallecido/>
She started as an announcer on ''{{ill|Club del sábado|es}}''.<ref name=fallecido/> Subsequently, she was on ''Panorama de actualidad'', with began her association with news services. In the mid-1960s she presented ''[[Telediario]]''.<ref name=Muere>{{Cite web |url=http://cadenaser.com/emisora/2018/01/09/radio_zaragoza/1515526703_987586.html |title=Muere la periodista jacetana Maruja Callaved a los 97 años |trans-title=The Jaca Journalist Maruja Callaved Dies at Age 97 |publisher=[[Cadena SER]] |language=Spanish |date=9 January 2018 |access-date=19 October 2018}}</ref> In 1963 she received the {{ill|Antena de Oro|es}} for her work in television.<ref name=Muere/>
Callaved's popularity increased with ''{{ill|Vamos a la mesa|es}}'' (1967),<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yQK3AAAAIAAJ&q=%22Maruja+Callaved%22+%22Vamos+a+la+mesa%22 |title=Españolas en la transición: de excluidas a protagonistas, 1973–1982 |trans-title=Spanish Women in the Transition: From Excluded to Protagonists, 1973–1982 |publisher=Biblioteca Nueva |isbn=9788470307263 |page=391 |language=Spanish |date=1 January 1999 |access-date=21 October 2018 |via=Google Books}}</ref> a predecessor of other cooking programs that would triumph decades later, such as [[Elena Santonja]]'s ''{{ill|Con las manos en la masa|es}}'' and ''{{ill|Karlos Arguiñano en tu cocina|es|lt=El menú de Karlos Arguiñano}}''.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.intereconomia.com/noticias-gaceta/opinion/una-jovencita-80-anos-20120319 |title=Una jovencita de 80 años |trans-title=An 80-Year-Old Girl |first=Marisa |last=Garrido |work=[[La Gaceta (Spain)|La Gaceta]] |language=Spanish |date=19 March 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120331051729/http://www.intereconomia.com/noticias-gaceta/opinion/una-jovencita-80-anos-20120319 |archive-date=31 March 2012 |dead-url=yes |access-date=19 October 2018}}</ref> A year later she presented ''Nivel de Vida'', together with [[Blanca Álvarez Mantilla|Blanca Álvarez]].<ref name=Muere/>
In the 1970s she got behind the camera and went on to direct, finding success with programs like ''Aquí y Ahora'' (1975) with [[José Luis Uribarri]], and ''{{ill|Gente hoy|es}}'' (1976–1981), a famous talk show that earned her the 1977 [[Premios Ondas|Ondas Award]],<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_Wova1u549MC&q=%22Los+Premios+Ondas+1977%22 |title=Blanco y negro, Volume 87, Issues 3413-3425 |page=93 |language=Spanish |year=1977 |access-date=19 October 2018 |via=Google Books}}</ref> and that launched the careers of presenters {{ill|Isabel Tenaille|es}} and [[Mari Cruz Soriano]].<ref name=fallecido/>
In 2017, Callaved received a heartfelt tribute in [[Huesca]], at the 1st Product and Gastronomy Congress of the Pyrenees. This was one of her last public appearances, at which she emotionally pointed out, "It is important for me and, from now on, in all the moments of my life. And what's more to do it in Huesca, that is my land and that allows me to speak with heart in hand."<ref>{{Cite magazine |url=http://www.rondasomontano.com/revista/114697/ |title=Maruja Callaved emocionó a los congresistas de Hecho en los Pirineos con su lúcido discurso |trans-title=Maruja Callaved Thrilled Legislators of Hecho en los Pirineos with Her Lucid Speech |work=Ronda Somontano |language=Spanish |date=22 March 2017 |access-date=19 October 2018}}</ref>

{{infobox theatre festival | theatre_festival_name = Minnesota Fringe Festival | image =[[File:Minnesota Fringe Festival logo dark, 2015 and 2016.tif|250px|center]] | caption = Current Fringe logo | location = Minneapolis, Minnesota | founded = 1994 | selector =[[Unjuried]] | founders = Bob McFadden | dates = August 2–12, 2018<ref>{{cite news|last1=Preston|first1=Rohan|title=Another leader steps down from the Minnesota Fringe Festival|url=http://www.startribune.com/another-leader-steps-down-from-the-minnesota-fringe-festival/397635311/|accessdate=January 19, 2017|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=October 19, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107041538/http://www.startribune.com/another-leader-steps-down-from-the-minnesota-fringe-festival/397635311/|archivedate=November 7, 2016}}</ref> (varies by year, see [[List of Minnesota Fringe Festivals|here]] for all past dates) | playtype = Comedy, drama, dance, musical, something different | website = {{url|http://fringefestival.org/}} }}
The '''Minnesota Fringe Festival''' is a performing arts festival held in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]], [[United States]], every summer, usually during the first two weeks in August. The eleven-day event, which features performing artists of many genres and disciplines, is one of many [[Fringe Festival]]s in [[North America]]. Minnesota Fringe is the largest nonjuried festival in the United States<ref name=2014stribstats>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe Festival hits new ticket record|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/blogs/270773461.html|accessdate=November 24, 2014|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 11, 2014}}</ref> and the third-largest Fringe festival in North America. In 2013, Minnesota Fringe ran August 1–11 and featured 176 shows with a total of 895 performances in multiple venues around the city and distributed 50,007 tickets over the eleven-day event. In 2007, attendance and box office revenue were adversely affected by the [[I-35W Mississippi River bridge|collapse of the I-35W bridge]] the day before the festival opened.
Fringe shows are 60 minutes or less and appear in an official venue supplied by the festival for five performances stretched out over the festival's eleven days. Venues vary widely, with capacities ranging from 55 to over 400, and available configurations include black-box, proscenium, thrust or arena stages. Past venues include Minneapolis Theatre Garage, [[HUGE Improv Theater]], [[Mixed Blood Theatre]] mainstage, [[Theatre de la Jeune Lune]]'s side stage and the four stages at the [[University of Minnesota]]'s [[Rarig Center]].<ref name=2014venues>{{cite news|title=Minnesota Fringe will have 20 Minneapolis venues|url=http://www.twincities.com/stage/ci_25426766/minnesota-fringe-will-have-20-minneapolis-venues|accessdate=November 24, 2014|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=March 26, 2014}}</ref> Normally, eleven shows will share a venue.
Performing companies that participate in the Fringe split a share of the ticket revenues with the festival and pay an application fee. Currently, the artists' share is 65 percent of the box office revenue.
The 2017 festival, which runs August 3-13, marks the 24th annual festival, the first under the leadership of executive director Dawn Bentley, who assumed this position on April 3, 2017,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Preston|first1=Rohan|title=A new director takes the helm at the Minnesota Fringe Festival|url=http://www.startribune.com/a-new-director-takes-the-helm-at-the-minnesota-fringe-festival/415000824/|accessdate=March 1, 2017|publisher=[[Star Tribune|Minneapolis Star Tribune]]|date=February 28, 2017}}</ref> after former executive director Jeff D. Larson stepped down in October 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hewitt|first1=Chris|title=Minnesota Fringe Festival finds a director|url=http://www.twincities.com/2017/02/28/minnesota-fringe-festival-finds-a-director/|accessdate=March 1, 2017|publisher=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=February 28, 2017}}</ref>
Minnesota Fringe Festival is a founding member of United States Association of Fringe Festivals (USAFF).<ref>{{cite web|title=What is Fringe?|url=http://www.fringefestivals.us/|publisher=United States Association of Fringe Festivals|accessdate=November 21, 2014}}</ref>
==History== {{further|List of Minnesota Fringe Festivals}} The Minnesota Fringe Festival was created as part of a trend of [[fringe festival]] establishments in the United States. The country's first fringe was the [[Seattle Fringe Festival]], founded in 1991, followed by the [[Orlando International Fringe Theater Festival]] and the [[San Francisco Fringe Festival]] in 1992 and 1993, respectively.<ref name="NA fests">{{cite news|last1=Hersh|first1=Amy|title=North American fringe fests: A new tradition that's growing|url=https://apps.hclib.org/auth/EDS?url=http%3a%2f%2fsearch.ebscohost.com%2flogin.aspx%3fdirect%3dtrue%26db%3dedb%26AN%3d9512033983%26site%3deds-live%26scope%3dsite|accessdate=June 14, 2016|work=[[Backstage (magazine)|Back Stage]]|date=November 17, 1995|subscription=yes|via=[[EBSCOHost]]}}</ref> Founded by Bob McFadden and operating with a budget of around $35,000, the Minnesota Fringe Festival first ran from June 23–July 2, 1994, in several theaters around the [[Cedar-Riverside, Minneapolis|West Bank]] neighborhood of [[Minneapolis]].<ref name="fringe at 20">{{cite news|title=Minnesota Fringe Festival at 20|first1=Rohan|last1=Preston|url=http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-fringe-festival-at-20/217176491/|date=August 1, 2013|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|archivedate=July 9, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160709230904/http://www.startribune.com/minnesota-fringe-festival-at-20/217176491/}}</ref><ref name="pizzato">{{cite journal|last1=Pizzato|first1=Mark|title=Minnesota Fringe Festival|journal=[[Theatre Journal]]|date=March 1995|volume=47|issue=1|pages=142–145|jstor=3208817|doi=10.2307/3208817}}</ref> In spite of the festival's name, the Minnesota Fringe did not serve as the fringe festival to any larger, more mainstream theater event. The first annual Fringe was described by Mark Pizzato as "quickly organized and underpublicized", with low attendance reported at its 53 shows, each of which cost six dollars or less and ran under 90 minutes.<ref name="pizzato" /> It drew 4,600 theatergoers and featured shows from companies hailing from three continents (North America, Asia, and Europe).<ref name="returns1995">{{cite news|last1=Abdallah|first1=Cheryl|title=Minnesota Fringe Festival Returns|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-2351423.html|accessdate=June 14, 2016|work=Asian Pages|date=June 30, 1995|subscription=yes|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}</ref>
The festival's growth was modest in its first several years. In 1997, following the previous year's festival which had seen the lowest attendance of any Fringe to date, the event moved to the [[Loring Park]] neighborhood.<ref name="loring">{{cite news|last1=Vaughan|first1=Peter|title=Grass is greener in Loring Park for Fringe|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62606945.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=March 16, 1997|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> That year marked an attendance of 4,300, after which point Dean Seal replaced McFadden as the festival's executive director.<ref name="seal steps down">{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe producer Seal steps down; festival reorganizes staff|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-78377664.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=September 18, 2001|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="passes">{{cite news|last1=Preston|first1=Rohan|title=Fringe getting bigger|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62564942.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 23, 1998|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> In 1998, the festival began offering patrons multi-show passes and attendance increased to 6,573.<ref name="passes" /> The following year, the festival's attendance more than doubled, owing, according to Fringe officials, to better marketing and the 68 shows at that years festival, an increase from previous years.<ref name="double">{{cite news|last1=Preston|first1=Rohan|title=Fans flocked to this year's Fringe Festival|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62458919.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 12, 1999|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> In 2000, the Fringe won a $10,000 grant from the [[McKnight Foundation]] and once more expanded, to 80 shows.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Preston|first1=Rohan|title=Boosting the Fringe|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62456545.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=April 23, 2000|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> Festival operations, with a working budget of $260,000, were run out of an office space above the Acadia Cabaret Cafe in Minneapolis, and the festival had begun attracting a variety of sponsors.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Peck|first1=Claude|title=Growth at the Fringe|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-63677082.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=July 23, 2000|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> While in its earlier years, acts had been selected by invitation, by the new millennium the festival was operating on an [[unjuried]] [[first-come, first-served]] model.<ref name="loring" /><ref name="2001 success">{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Success presses Fringe|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-76875872.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=July 29, 2001|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> The 2001 festival marked the first year that Fringe organizers had to turn away applicants, with the number of shows capped at 120.<ref name="2001 success" /> The festival had also expanded into screening films and showcasing visual art as part of the Visual Fringe.<ref name="on the move">{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe is on the move|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-88131007.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=June 30, 2002|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Seal, the only full-time Fringe employee, resigned as the festival's executive director in 2001 and was replaced by Leah Cooper, who had for the previous three years served as president of the organization's board.<ref name="on the move" /><ref name="new fringe boss">{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=New Fringe boss|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-81123285.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=December 16, 2001|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> Early in her tenure, Cooper hired a full-time volunteer coordinator, a director for Visual Fringe, and a part-time office manager. The 2002 festival was the first in a number of years to employ venues outside of Loring Park, expanding the festival's footprint to the [[Uptown, Minneapolis|Uptown]] district. By this point, the Minnesota Fringe was the United States's largest fringe festival.<ref name="on the move" /> In the following years, the festival's most popular shows saw increased attendance, including record numbers of sold-out houses, as well as reprises and remounts at other venues, while mean attendance decreased, indicating decreased attendance at smaller shows.<ref name="fifteen">{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe Festival attendance rose 15.3%|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-120860970.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 18, 2004|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref name="flowering">{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Flowering Fringe|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-120279765.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 6, 2004|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> Cooper in 2004 announced plans to exit the Fringe after the 2005 festival, but stayed on an additional year to help solve fundraising issues that arose.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Leah Cooper to quit Fringe Festival|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-122114236.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=September 16, 2004|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe fest director says she is leaving|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-146700256.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=June 6, 2006|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> In 2006, the festival began using venues in the West Bank neighborhood again.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe fest adds U's Rarig Center to its stages|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-143738607.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=March 26, 2006|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Robin Gillette replaced Cooper as executive director for the 2007 festival.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Papatola|first1=Dominic P.|title=Gillette will lead next year's Fringe fest|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-149427077.html|accessdate=July 9, 2016|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=August 13, 2006|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> On August 1 of that year, the [[I-35W Mississippi River bridge]] collapsed. That year's iteration of the festival was scheduled to begin the next day and the bridge would have connected patrons to neighborhoods in which performances were to take place. As a result of the bridge's collapse, attendance to the festival was 17% lower than the year before, the lowest since 2002.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |last=Martin |first=Judith A. |editor-last1=Nunnally |editor-first1=Patrick |title=Neighborhoods Confront a Disaster Aftermath |encyclopedia=The City, the River, the Bridge: Before and After the Minneapolis Bridge Collapse |date=2011 |publisher=University of Minnesota Press|location=Minneapolis|page=72|isbn=978-0-8166-6767-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Bridge collapse reverberated into festival attendance|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-167709456.html|accessdate=July 28, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 16, 2007|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> The 2008 festival saw an increase in the number of dance shows presented as well as a partial recovery in the number of tickets sold and by 2009, the festival set an all-time attendance record of more than 46,000.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lefevre|first1=Camille|title=Dancing their way to the Fringe|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-182353084.html|accessdate=July 28, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 1, 2008|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe Festival bounces back after a down year|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-183265819.html|accessdate=July 28, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 12, 2008|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Horgen|first1=Tom|title=Fringe Festival wraps up with a record-high attendance|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-205641311.html|accessdate=July 28, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=August 11, 2009|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Jeff Larson, who first worked administratively with the Fringe as its technical director, then associate director, became executive director in 2013.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Fringe Fest in the black|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-172072874.html|accessdate=July 28, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=November 18, 2007|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Royce|first1=Graydon|title=Flustered by the Fringe? Tips on Choosing Shows|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-298067806.html|accessdate=July 28, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=July 29, 2012|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Preston|first1=Rohan|title=Tribe of the Fringe|url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-338130100.html|accessdate=July 28, 2016|work=[[Star Tribune]]|date=July 28, 2013|via=[[HighBeam Research]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> He left the position in 2016.<ref name="larson steps down">{{cite news|last1=Gabler|first1=Jay|title=Jeff Larson steps down after 3 years as Fringe Fest executive director|url=http://www.citypages.com/arts/jeff-larson-steps-down-after-3-years-as-fringe-fest-executive-director/396078421|accessdate=October 6, 2016|work=[[City Pages]]|date=October 5, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006142852/http://www.citypages.com/arts/jeff-larson-steps-down-after-3-years-as-fringe-fest-executive-director/396078421|archivedate=October 6, 2016}}</ref>
==Features of the Minnesota Fringe== [[File:The Donner Party Kidz!.jpg|thumb|right|''The Donner Party Kidz!'', a show from the 2012 Festival]] ===Nonjuried entry=== Minnesota Fringe Festival is nonjuried; that is, the performers and shows are not vetted by a panel of judges ahead of time. Companies that wish to perform submit applications and are drawn by lottery, a practice that replaced the festival's former method of "first come, first served" in 2004.
===Performance categories=== The festival is open to all performing artists. Show genres typically include comedy (scripted and improv), drama, dance (classical, modern and ethnic), puppetry, musical theater, opera and shows for/by children and teens. Minnesota Fringe, like many fringe festivals, has proven to be an excellent launching point for new work.<ref>[http://www.2amtheatre.com/2010/08/19/the-minnesota-fringe-festival-and-the-popularity-of-new-plays/ "The Minnesota Fringe Festival and the Popularity of New Plays"]; 2AMt blog, Max "Bunny" Sparber; 19 August 2010</ref>
===Accessibility=== Each venue is wheelchair-accessible and the festival offers ASL-interpreted shows for the deaf and hard-of-hearing, as well as audio-described shows for the blind.<ref name=access>{{cite news|title=Accessible Fringe Festival Returns for 13th Season|url=http://www.accesspress.org/archive/2006/07/story_accessible_fringe_festival.htm|accessdate=November 24, 2014|work=Access Press|date=July 10, 2006|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061014133421/http://www.accesspress.org/archive/2006/07/story_accessible_fringe_festival.htm|archivedate=October 14, 2006}}</ref>
==="Bring Your Own Venue"=== In the past, Minnesota Fringe has provided an option for companies to produce site-specific work outside the official venues. The Bring Your Own Venue (BYOV) option was only available for shows that could not normally fit into a traditional theater space. Past BYOV shows have been staged in places such as a clothing store dressing area, a swimming pool, an art gallery and a coffee shop. In 2006, 23 shows, a record number, performed in BYOV slots.<ref>Papatola, Dominic; [http://www.twincities.com/mld/twincities/entertainment/performing_arts/15181139.htm "Wrinkle in the rules requires some fringers to get a place lift"]; St. Paul Pioneer Press; 3 August 2006</ref>
===Website=== The [http://www.fringefestival.org Minnesota Fringe Festival Website] operates year-round. All of the shows in the yearly festival are up for review by any audience member who registers on the site. Shows are rated on a scale of 0 to 5 stars along with a written review. Each show is assigned an overall star rating based on the average of all the reviews received. Minnesota Fringe also retains a staff of photographers who attend shows and return photographs for the festival's daily slide show. During the six-week 2013 festival period, the site received over a million pageviews.
==Statistics== {{main article|List of Minnesota Fringe Festivals#Festivals}} [[File:Jumpin' Jack Kerouac 1, MN Fringe, August 2014.jpg|thumb|right|''Jumpin' Jack Kerouac'' at the [[University of Minnesota|U of M]] [[Rarig Center|Rarig]] Proscenium in 2014|alt=Three men in hats and beige or brown outfits dance on a dark stage]] '''Shows'''<br /> 2014: 169<ref name=2014report>{{cite web|title=Minnesota Fringe: The 2014 Annual Report|url=http://www.fringefestival.org/perch/resources/1415296645-minnesota-fringe-2014-annual-report.pdf|publisher=Minnesota Fringe Festival|accessdate=November 21, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141121030145/http://www.fringefestival.org/perch/resources/1415296645-minnesota-fringe-2014-annual-report.pdf|archivedate=November 21, 2014|page=4|format=PDF|date=2014}}</ref><br /> 2013: 176<br /> 2012: 163<br /> 2011: 167<br /> 2010: 169<br /> 2009: 162<br /> 2008: 156
'''Performances'''<br /> 2014: 878<ref name=2014report /><br /> 2013: 895<br /> 2012: 829<br /> 2011: 865<br /> 2010: 876<br /> 2009: 843<br /> 2008: 808
'''Ticket Sales'''<br /> 2014: 50,265<ref name=2014report /><br /> 2013: 50,007<br /> 2012: 46,284<br /> 2011: 48,432<br /> 2010: 50,256<br /> 2009: 46,217<br /> 2008: 40,926
'''Total Artist Payout'''<br /> 2014: $258,738<ref name=2014report /><br /> 2013: $245,223<ref name="2013 pipress tickets">{{cite news|title=2013 Fringe Festival tops 50,000 tickets|url=http://www.twincities.com/stage/ci_24015132/2013-fringe-tops-50-000-tickets?|accessdate=November 21, 2014|work=[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]|date=September 5, 2013}}</ref><br /> 2012: $230,997<br /> 2011: $243,792<ref name="2011annualreport">{{cite web|title=Minnesota Fringe: 2011 annual report|url=http://www.fringefestival.org/press/releases/MN-Fringe-2011-annual-report.pdf|publisher=Minnesota Fringe Festival|accessdate=November 21, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130223121815/http://www.fringefestival.org/press/releases/MN-Fringe-2011-annual-report.pdf|archivedate=February 23, 2013|format=PDF|date=2011}}</ref><br /> 2010: $249,116<br /> 2009: $215,600<br /> 2008: $193,293

{{notability|1=Biographies|date=July 2017}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Mohammed Ramzi | other_names = Nadhim Ramzi | image = | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1928|07|14}} | birth_place = [[Baghdad]], Iraq | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2013|09|18|1928|07|14}} | death_place = London, England | occupation = photographer | known_for = photographer, designer, artist | notable_works = Iraq:The land and the people | website = {{URL|ramzi.co.uk/}} }} '''Nadhim Ramzi''' ({{lang-ar|ناظم رمزي}}; 14 July 1928 – 18 September 2013 from a [[Kurdish people|Kurdish]] family) was an Iraqi [[graphic designer]], [[calligrapher]], photographer, and painter best known for documenting life in Iraq from the 1950s by photography.<ref>{{cite news |last=Photographer Bio |first= |title=Iraq, the land and the people|url=https://books.google.iq/books?id=KMqePQAACAAJ&dq=iraq+the+land+and+the+people&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi54KD6gJ3SAhVGb5oKHSYKCroQ6AEIGjAA |agency=(1977) Iraqi Cultural Centre}}</ref>
==Life and career == Nadhim Ramzi was born in Baghdad into a family of Kurdish background. In his youth, Ramzi began to recognize the beauty of his natural environment and the local people in various parts of Iraq due to his father's constant movement. His father was administrative staff member during 1934–1944; Ramzi liked birds hunting and learned to draw them. He also loved the wilderness and the native people. Ramzi started to get involved and participate in a lot of hobbies that affected his future.<ref name="Hamid"/>
In Al-[[Yusufiyah]] he started practicing [[Islamic geometric patterns]] and became obsessed with it, and in [[Khan Bani Saad]] he found happiness in the life of the countryside and grazing sheep: "It was to this small village a great impact on my lifestyle and behavior. He watched artisans making carpets and ceramics, which aroused his interest in traditional design. He taught himself to paint at a very young age. <ref name="moo"/><ref name="Hamid"/>
And in [[Al-Mahawil District]] he got in touch with the ancient hills and ruins of the [[Babylonia]]n civilization, amazed and inspired by [[Art of Mesopotamia]] that has survived for decades.<ref name="Hamid">{{cite news|last=Mai Muzaffar (25 September 2013)|first=|title=The Iraqi artist N.Ramzi:In love with the land and people|url=http://www.alquds.co.uk/?p=87224|date=|language=Arabic |agency=Al-Quds Al-Arabi}}</ref>
Ramzi started photography as a hobby at the age of 16, when he received his first camera as a gift. "<ref name="moo">{{cite news|last= |first=|title=From the memory|url=|date=|agency=a book by N.Ramzi}}</ref>
In an interview, Ramzi's good friend, Rifat Chidirji, described the photographer's approach:
{{block quote| Nadhim Ramzi was a very good friend of mine, and I knew of Latif Al-Ani's work through publications and exhibitions. They photographed with an attention to aesthetics, looking for beautiful compositions. I photographed things as they are. One day, I went out to take photographs with Nadhim Ramzi. We saw a bench. I immediately took several photographs, focusing on its structure. Ramzi went around it for about five minutes, and he ended up taking one image only. That was the difference between us. I documented quickly and moved on.<ref>Alsaden, A., "Capturing Evanescence: Rifat Chadirji and Balkis Sharara in conversation with Amin Alsaden," ''Ibraaz,'' 16 November 2016 [https://www.ibraaz.org/interviews/206 Online:]</ref>}}
===Ramzi's Printing Company=== Ramzi's traveled to Paris in 1964 where he stayed for two years and was introduced to printing methods and its techniques, He founded a printing company in [[Baghdad]] and named it after his name,<ref name="Hamid"/> It was one of the best printing companies in Iraq, it was located near Al Rasheed Camp's main road. The company was established in 70s and founded by Ramzi himself. It offered a variety of printing products and services with a focus on quality, and service.<ref name="nkad"/>
It contained three main departments:<ref name="nkad">{{cite news|last= |first=|title=The departure of the Iraqi art|url=http://www.alnaked-aliraqi.net/article/18404.php|date=|language=Arabic |agency=Al Mada Newspaper}}</ref> # Technical Workshop (Managed by Ramzi him self) # Financial Department(Supervised by Lawyer Mehdi Ali Zaini) # Printing Department (Managed by Mryosh Faleh)
==Work == ===Exhibitions=== ====One man show==== * '''1958''' – ''Photography Exhibition,'' Baghdad. * '''1972''' – ''Political Cartoons Exhibition,'' Baghdad. * '''1977''' – ''Photography Exhibition,'' Iraqi Cultural Center, London.<ref name="yudoc">{{cite news|last= |first=|title=YouTube Document|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qaCelzxOnwo|date=|language=Arabic |agency=Al Tariq – Righa}}</ref> * '''2010''' – ''Last Exhibition,'' Baghdad.<ref name="doc1">{{cite news|last= |first=|title=Article Abot N.Ramzi|url=https://www.azzaman.com/?p=43834|date=|language=Arabic |agency=Azzaman}}</ref>
====Group Exhibitions==== * '''1956–1960''' – ''S.P Group Exhibition,'' Iraqi Artist Society, Baghdad. * '''1957''' – ''Iraqi Modern Art,'' Beirut. * '''1970''' – ''Iraqi Poster Exhibition,'' National Gallery of Modern Art, Baghdad. * '''1977''' – ''Six Iraqi Artist,'' National Gallery of Modern Art, Baghdad. * '''1980''' – ''Seven Iraqi Artist,'' Iraqi Cultural Center, London.:<ref name="yudoc"/>
====Publications ==== Ramzi published a number of books, mostly consisting of his photographs, including:
* ''Iraq: The Land and The People,'' London, Iraqi Cultural Centre, (1977) 1989 * ''From the Memory,'' Beirut, 2008 * ''Iraq: Photography Of Some Features Of The Life In The Twentieth Century,'' Beirut, 2009 * ''My Journey With The Camera,'' Amman, 2010
==See also== * [[Arabesque]] * [[Iraqi art]] * [[Islamic art]] * [[List of Iraqi artists]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox writer | name = Oliver Gogarty | image = Orpen_OSJGogarty.jpg | caption = Oliver Gogarty as painted in 1911 by [[William Orpen]] | birth_name = Oliver Joseph St. John Gogarty | birth_date = {{Birth date|1878|8|17|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Parnell Square|Rutland Square]], Dublin, Ireland | death_date = {{death date and age|1957|9|22|1878|8|17|df=y}} | death_place = New York City, United States | spouse = Martha Duane Gogarty | occupation = Author, poet, memoirist, surgeon, politician, athlete | movement = Irish Literary Renaissance | notableworks = ''[[As I Was Going Down Sackville Street]]'' (1937)}}
{{MedalTop}} {{MedalSport | [[Art competitions at the Summer Olympics|Art competitions]]}} {{MedalBronze | [[1924 Summer Olympics|1924 Paris]] | [[Art competitions at the 1924 Summer Olympics|Literature]]}} {{MedalBottom}}
'''Oliver Joseph St John Gogarty''' (17 August 1878 – 22 September 1957) was an Irish poet, author, [[otolaryngologist]], athlete, politician, and well-known conversationalist. He served as the inspiration for [[Buck Mulligan]] in [[James Joyce]]'s novel ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]]''.
==Life==
===Early life=== Gogarty was born 17 August 1878 in [[Parnell Square|Rutland Square]], Dublin, the eldest child of Henry Gogarty, a well-to-do Dublin physician, and Margaret Gogarty (née Oliver), the daughter of a [[Galway]] mill owner.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://civilrecords.irishgenealogy.ie/churchrecords/details-civil/7adc675723754|title=General Registrar's Office|last=|first=|date=|website=IrishGenealogy.ie|publisher=|access-date=17 August 2017}}</ref> Three siblings (Henry, Mary, and Richard) were born later. Gogarty's father, himself the son of a medical doctor, had been educated at [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]] and owned two fashionable homes in Dublin, which set the Gogartys apart from other [[Irish Catholic]] families at that time and allowed them access to the same social circles as the [[Protestant Ascendancy]].<ref>O'Connor, pp.12-13</ref>
In 1887 Gogarty's father died of a [[Appendicitis|burst appendix]], and Gogarty was sent to [[Mungret College]], a boarding school near [[Limerick]]. He was unhappy in his new school, and the following year he transferred to [[Stonyhurst College]] in Lancashire, England, which he liked little better, later referring to it as "a religious jail".<ref>{{cite book |title= It Isn't This Time of Year at All! |last= Gogarty |first= Oliver |year= 1954 |publisher= Doubleday & Company, Inc. |location= New York |page= 41}}</ref>
Gogarty returned to Ireland in 1896 and boarded at [[Clongowes Wood College]] while studying for examinations with the [[Royal University of Ireland]]. He was a talented athlete; in England he had briefly played for the [[Preston North End FC]] Reserve, and while at [[Clongowes Wood College|Clongowes]] he played for the [[Bohemian FC]]. He also played on Clongowes's soccer and [[cricket]] elevens. His extracurricular interests, which also included cycling and drinking, prevented him from being an attentive student, and in 1898 he switched to the medical school at [[Trinity College, Dublin|Trinity College]], having failed eight of his ten [[examinations]] at the [[Royal University of Ireland|Royal]].<ref>O'Connor, pp. 14–16</ref>
===University days=== As one of [[Dublin]]'s "[[medical student|medicos]]", Gogarty was known to be fond of public [[pranks]]<ref>O'Connor, pp. 22–23</ref> and midnight carousing in "the Kips", Dublin's red-light district.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 54–55</ref> He had a talent for [[light poetry|humorous]] and [[ribaldry|bawdy verse]], which quickly made the rounds through the city, and sometimes composed [[mnemonic]] lyrics to aid his [[medical school|medical studies]]. He also enjoyed a highly successful cycling career before being banned from the tracks in 1901 for bad language, and between 1898 and 1901 he rescued at least four people from drowning.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 24–25, 39</ref> He became interested in [[Irish nationalism]] after meeting [[Arthur Griffith]] in 1899, and contributed propaganda pieces to ''[[United Irishman|The United Irishman]]'' over subsequent years.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 92–93</ref>
[[File:OSJGogarty1897.jpg|thumb|left|Gogarty in 1897]]
A serious interest in poetry and literature also began to manifest itself during his years at Trinity. His witty conversation made him a favourite with the [[university don|dons]], particularly [[John Pentland Mahaffy]] (formerly the tutor of [[Oscar Wilde]]) and [[Robert Yelverton Tyrrell]], and between 1901 and 1903 he won three successive Vice-Chancellor's prizes for verse. In 1900 he made the acquaintance of [[W. B. Yeats]] (of whom his mother highly approved) and of [[George Moore (novelist)|George Moore]] (of whom she did not) and began to frequent [[Celtic revival|Dublin literary circles]].<ref>O'Connor, pp. 29–30</ref> He also formed close friendships with other up-and-coming young poets, such as [[Seamus O'Sullivan]] and [[James Joyce]]. In 1904 he spent two [[academic term|terms]] at [[Oxford]] to compete for the [[Newdigate Prize]], but lost to [[George Bell (bishop)|G.K.A. Bell]], the future [[Bishop of Chichester]], who became a friend and frequent correspondent over the next few years.<ref>O'Connor, pp71-75</ref>
[[File:James Joyce Martello Tower.jpg|thumb|right|The Tower in Sandycove]]
Upon returning to Dublin in the summer of 1904, Gogarty made arrangements to rent the famous [[James Joyce Tower|Martello Tower in Sandycove]]. The primary goal of this scheme, as described by Gogarty in a letter to G.K.A. Bell, was to "house the Bard" (i.e. James Joyce), who was without money and required "a year in which to finish his novel."<ref>{{cite book |title= Many Lines to Thee |last= Carens |first= James |year= 1972 |publisher= Dolmen Press |location= Dublin |page= 16}}</ref> The two friends quarrelled in August, however, and Joyce either failed to move in or left shortly after doing so. Joyce briefly took up residence in the [[James Joyce Tower|Tower]] the following month, together with Gogarty and his Oxford friend Samuel Chenevix Trench (a setup which later provided inspiration for the opening chapter of ''[[Ulysses (novel)|Ulysses]])'' but left again suddenly after only six days.<ref>Ellman, p.175</ref> Forty years later in America, Gogarty would attribute Joyce's abrupt departure to his and S.C. Trench's midnight antics with a loaded [[revolver]].<ref>{{cite book |title= Mourning Became Mrs. Spendlove |last= Gogarty |first= Oliver |year= 1948 |publisher= Creative Age Press |location= New York |pages= 56–57}}</ref> Joyce and Gogarty corresponded intermittently during the early years of Joyce's continental exile and occasionally planned meetings, but contemporaneous letters from Joyce to his brother reveal deep distrust of Gogarty's motives,<ref>Ellmann, p. 842</ref> and their friendship was never fully renewed. Gogarty made use of the Martello Tower during the following year as a writing retreat and party venue, and officially held the lease until 1925.
In 1904 and 1905 Gogarty published several short poems in the London publication ''The Venture'' and in [[William Kirkpatrick Magee|John Eglinton]]'s journal ''Dana''.<ref>Carens (1979) p. 22</ref> His name also appeared in print as the renegade priest Fr. Oliver Gogarty in George Moore's 1905 novel ''The Lake'', an occurrence which upset Gogarty's devout mother.<ref>O'Connor, 107–108</ref> In 1905 Gogarty became one of the founding members of [[Arthur Griffith]]'s [[Sinn Féin]], a [[nonviolent revolution|non-violent political movement]] with a plan for Irish autonomy modelled after the [[Austria-Hungary|Austro-Hungarian dual monarchy]].<ref>O'Connor, p. 89</ref>
===Medical career and family=== [[File:Nollgogarty.jpg|thumb|right|Noll Gogarty, painted by [[William Orpen]]]] In August 1906, Gogarty married Martha Duane, a girl from a landowning [[Connemara]] family. Eager to establish himself with a profession, he passed his final medical examinations in June 1907, several months after the death of his mother. In July 1907 his first son, Oliver Duane Odysseus Gogarty (known as "Noll") was born, and in autumn of that year Gogarty left for [[Vienna]] to finish the practical phase of his medical training. Owing in part to the influence of his mentor, [[Robert Henry Woods|Sir Robert Woods]], Gogarty had decided to specialise in [[otolaryngology]], and in [[Vienna]] he studied under [[Ottokar Chiari]], Markus Hajek, and [[Robert Bárány]].
Returning to Dublin in 1908, Gogarty secured a post at Richmond Hospital, and shortly afterwards purchased a house in Ely Place opposite George Moore. Three years later, he joined the staff of the [[Meath Hospital]] and remained there for the remainder of his medical career. He became known for flamboyant theatrics in the [[operating room]], including off-the-cuff witticisms and the flinging of recently removed [[larynx]]es at the viewing gallery. He also maintained [[otolaryngology|ENT]] consulting rooms in [[Ely Place]], attracting a number of wealthy clients and attending to less well-off patients for free.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 113–127</ref>
Gogarty and his wife went on to have two more children, [[Dermot St. John Gogarty|Dermot]] (born 1908) and Brenda (born 1911), and in 1917 Gogarty purchased Renyvle House, a large [[country house]] in [[Renvyle]], [[Connemara]]. He became a keen [[motorist]] during this time, purchasing a succession of [[cars]] that culminated with a buttercup-coloured [[Rolls-Royce Limited|Rolls Royce]].<ref>O'Connor, p. 121</ref> During the following decade he was also interested in aviation, earning a [[pilot's licence]] and helping to found the Irish Aero Club.<ref>O'Connor, p. 232</ref>
===Free State Senator=== As a [[Sinn Féin]]er during the [[Irish War of Independence]], Gogarty participated in a variety of anti-[[Black and Tans|Black and Tan]] schemes, allowing his home to be used as a [[safe house]] and transporting disguised [[Irish Republican Army|IRA]] volunteers in his car.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 173–174</ref> Following the [[ratification]] of the [[Anglo-Irish Treaty]], Gogarty sided with the [[Irish Free State|pro-Treaty government]] (headed by his close friend [[Arthur Griffith]]) and was made a [[Seanad Éireann|Free State Senator]].<ref name=oireachtas_db>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtas.ie/members-hist/default.asp?housetype=1&HouseNum=1922&MemberID=1338&ConstID=214|title=Dr. Oliver St. John Gogarty|work=Oireachtas Members Database|accessdate=16 January 2016}}</ref> When Griffith fell ill during the summer of 1922, Gogarty frequently attended his bedside. His death on 12 August 1922 had a profound effect on Gogarty; W.T. Cosgrave later observed that "he was almost mortally wounded when Griffith died, he was so very, very much attached to him."<ref>{{cite book |title= Irish Literary Portraits |last= Rodgers |first= William |year= 1973 |publisher= Taplinger Publishers |location= New York |page= 153}}</ref> Gogarty carried out Griffith's official [[autopsy]] and [[embalmment]], and went on to perform the same offices for [[Michael Collins (Irish leader)|Michael Collins]], another close friend whom Gogarty had often sheltered in his Ely Place home prior to his assassination. It was rumoured that Griffith had been planning to make Gogarty the new [[Governor-General of the Irish Free State]], but in his absence the post went to [[Timothy Michael Healy|Tim Healy]].<ref>O'Connor, p. 97</ref>
[[File:Gogarty1922.jpg|thumb|left|Gogarty in 1922]]
In November 1922, anti-Treaty [[Irish Republican Army|IRA]] commander [[Liam Lynch (Irish republican)|Liam Lynch]] issued a general order to his forces to shoot [[Seanad Éireann|Free State Senators]]. Two months later, Gogarty was [[Kidnapping|kidnapped]] by a group of anti-Treaty militants, who lured him out of his house and into a waiting car under the pretext of bringing him to visit a sick patient. Gogarty was subsequently driven to an empty house near [[Chapelizod]] and held under armed guard. Aware that he might be in imminent danger of execution, Gogarty contrived to have himself led out into the garden (purportedly by claiming to be suffering from [[diarrhoea]]), where he broke free from his captors and flung himself into the [[River Liffey|Liffey]]; he then swam to shore and delivered himself to the protection of the police barracks in [[Phoenix Park]]. In February of that same year, [[Destruction of Irish country houses (1919-1923)|Renvyle was burnt to the ground]] by anti-Treaty forces. Following these incidents, Gogarty relocated his family and practice to London, where he resided until February 1924. Upon returning to Ireland, he famously released two swans into the [[River Liffey]] in gratitude for his life.<ref>O'Connor, pp. 194–199</ref>
Gogarty remained a senator until the abolition of the [[Seanad Éireann|Seanad]] in 1936, during which time he identified with none of the existing political parties and voted according to his own whims. He believed that Ireland should retain its dominion status in the [[British Commonwealth]] so as to "keep with nations who understand that the first principle of freedom is a freedom that does not permit interference with the personal liberties of the citizen." He supported rural electrification schemes, road improvement, [[reforestation]] and [[Conservation movement|conservation]], prevention of livestock cruelty, and [[educational reform]]. His views on controversial issues such as censorship and [[birth control]] were ambiguous; after expressing initial support for the Censorship Bill, he eventually went on to denounce it in scathing terms ("I think it is high time the men of this country found some other way of loving God than by hating women"), and while generally professing to oppose the sale of prophylactics, he voiced support for their usage in certain cases. He was most passionate on the subject of sanitation in schools and in urban and rural housing, about which he spoke frequently.<ref>Carens (1979) pp.112–113</ref> His speeches frequently contained [[pun]]s, wordplays, and extended poetic quotations, and were sometimes given in favour of facetious schemes, such as his attempt to have the [[Phoenix (mythology)|phoenix]] statue in [[Phoenix Park]] included in the 1929 Wild Birds Protection Bill.<ref>Historical Debates Website. Seanad Éireann Wild Birds Protection Bill, 1929—Report. Tithe an Oireachteas. 19 August 2009. {{cite web |url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0013/S.0013.192912120007 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607135429/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0013/S.0013.192912120007 |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He was notoriously scornful of the government's attempts to reinstate the [[Irish language]] (which he referred to as "Woolworth's Irish"), proposing that funding be used instead for housing and school health services,<ref>Historical Debates Website. Seanad Éireann Central Fund Bill, 1936—Report and Final Stages. Tithe an Oireachteas. 19 August 2009. {{cite web |url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0020/S.0020.193603250004.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110607135500/http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/S/0020/S.0020.193603250004.html |archivedate=7 June 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and remained perpetually suspicious of [[Éamon de Valera]], against whose economic policies, character, and personal appearance he often hurled invectives during Seanad proceedings. [[Éamon de Valera|De Valera]] eventually dissolved the Seanad when it persisted in obstructing Government proposals, effectively ending Gogarty's political career.<ref>O'Connor, pp.246–254</ref>
===Literary endeavours=== Gogarty maintained close friendships with [[W. B. Yeats]], [[George William Russell|AE]], George Moore, [[Lord Dunsany]], [[James Stephens (author)|James Stephens]], [[Seamus O'Sullivan]], and other Dublin literati, and continued to write poetry in the midst of his political and professional duties. Three small books of poetry (''Hyperthuleana'', ''Secret Springs of Dublin Song'', and ''The Ship and Other Poems'') were published between 1916 and 1918.<ref>Carens, pp. 31–37</ref> Gogarty also tried his hand at [[playwriting]], producing a slum drama (''[[Blight (play)|Blight]]'') in 1917 under the pseudonym "Alpha and Omega", and two comedies (''A Serious Thing'' and ''The Enchanted Trousers'') in 1919 under the pseudonym "[[Gideon Ouseley]]", all three of which were performed at the [[Abbey Theatre]].<ref>Carens, pp. 42–46</ref>
Gogarty devoted less energy to his medical practice and more to his writing during the twenties and thirties. His 1924 book of poetry ''An Offering of Swans'' won the Gold Medal for poetry at the revived [[Tailteann Games (Irish Free State)|Tailteann Games]], for which he also wrote the 1924 Olympic bronze medal-winning ''Tailteann Ode'' (which he was later to describe as "rather tripe").<ref>Carens, p. 23</ref> In 1929 another book of verse, ''Wild Apples'', was published, and was followed in 1933 by ''Selected Poems''. Gogarty was also a member of [[W. B. Yeats|Yeats]]'s Irish Academy of Letters and frequently assisted in arranging its social functions. 1936 saw the publication of [[W. B. Yeats|Yeats]]'s ''[[Oxford Book of Modern Verse]]'', which contained seventeen of Gogarty's poems and an introduction proclaiming him "one of the great lyric poets of our age."<ref>O'Connor, p. 255</ref> The over-representation given to Gogarty outraged many poets and perplexed Gogarty himself, who remarked, "What right have I to figure so bulkily? None from a poetical point of view... [[Sappho]] herself could not have made a more subjective anthology."<ref>Carens, p. 266</ref>
In 1935 Gogarty published his first prose work, ''[[As I Was Going Down Sackville Street]]'' (subtitled "A Phantasy in Fact"), a semi-fictional novel-memoir that tells, in reverse chronological order, the story of Gogarty's Dublin through a series of interconnected anecdotes and lively characters sketches. Shortly after its publication, it became the subject of a lawsuit by a Jewish [[art dealer]], Harry Sinclair, who claimed that he and his recently deceased twin brother, William Sinclair, had been [[libel]]ed by the publication. The two men did not appear as named characters in the book, but some derogatory lines of verse beginning ''"Two Jews grew in Sackville Street"'', written by Gogarty's friend George Redding and included in a scene in the novel, were widely known to refer to the Sinclair siblings. Harry Sinclair further recognised a reference to his grandfather, described in the text as one who "enticed little girls into his office", an offence of which his grandfather had in fact been convicted. Gogarty responded to the charges by claiming that the unnamed Jews were parodies or composite characters rather than deliberate evocations of living persons.<ref>O'Connor, pp.280–283</ref> The case attracted a great deal of public attention, with one commentator observing that "only ''[[The Pickwick Papers]]'', rewritten by James Joyce, could really capture the mood of this trial."<ref>O'Connor, p. 279</ref> Among the witnesses for the prosecution was William Sinclair's nephew-by-marriage, [[Samuel Beckett]], then a little-known writer, who was humiliatingly denounced as a "bawd and blasphemer" by Gogarty's counsel.<ref>{{cite book |title= Damned to Fame: The Life of Samuel Beckett |last= Knowlson |first= James |year= 1996 |publisher= Bloomsbury |location= London}}</ref> Gogarty ultimately lost the lawsuit and was ordered to pay £900 in damages, plus court costs. This outcome deeply embittered Gogarty, who had already suffered financial setbacks after the [[stock market crash of 1929]]<ref>{{cite book |title= W. B. Yeats: A Life, Vol. II: The Arch-Poet 1915–1939 |last= Foster |first= Robert |year= 2003 |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= Oxford |page= 405}}</ref> and felt that the verdict had been politically motivated.<ref>O'Connor, p. 284</ref>
In spite of the ''Sackville Street'' imbroglio, Gogarty's output over the next two years was prolific. In 1938 he published ''I Follow St. Patrick'', a historical and geographic portrait of Ireland as told through Gogarty's rambling visits to various sites traditionally associated with [[St. Patrick]]; in 1939 he published ''Tumbling in the Hay'', a semi-autobiographical comic novel about medical students in turn-of-the-century Dublin, and ''Elbow Room'', another collection of poetry. In 1938 he relocated to London for a second time and brought forth his own libel suit against the young poet [[Patrick Kavanagh]], whose autobiography ''The Green Fool'' said of [[Patrick Kavanagh|Kavanagh]]'s first visit to Gogarty's home: "I mistook Gogarty's white-robed maid for his wife or his mistress; I expected every poet to have a spare wife." Gogarty, who had taken offence at the close coupling of the words "wife" and "mistress", was awarded £100 in damages.<ref>{{cite book |title= Patrick Kavanagh |last= O'Brien |first= Darcy |year= 1975 |publisher= Bucknell University Press |location= Lewisburg |page= 29}}</ref>
===American years=== With the onset of [[World War II]], Gogarty, who was an enthusiastic and talented amateur [[aviator]], attempted to enlist in the [[RAF]] and the [[RAMC]] as a doctor. He was denied on grounds of age. He then departed in September 1939 for an extended lecture tour in the United States, leaving his wife to manage Renvyle House, which had since been rebuilt as a hotel. When his return to Ireland was delayed by the war, Gogarty applied for [[American citizenship]], and eventually decided to reside permanently in the United States. Though he regularly sent letters, funds, and care-packages to his family and returned home for occasional holiday visits, he never again lived in Ireland for any extended length of time. His primary American residence was in New York, where he was known to frequent bars on [[Third Avenue]]. He also spent time in [[Vermont]] and in Wyckoff, [[New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite book |title= The Renvyle Letters |last= Williams |first= Guy |year= 2000 |publisher= Daletta Press |location= Monasterevan |pages= 1–2}}</ref>
Feeling that he was too old to sit for the medical examinations that would have qualified him as a practitioner in the United States, Gogarty instead chose to support himself entirely by his writing. In addition to various essays and short stories, his prose output included ''Going Native'', a satire on English social mores, ''Mad Grandeur'' and ''Mr. Petunia'', two period narratives composed with an eye to having them optioned as Hollywood films, and ''Rolling Down the Lea'' and ''It Isn't This Time of Year at All!'', two loosely constructed memoirs. He also published two books of poems, ''Perennial'' and ''Unselected Poems''; a collection of bawdy verse, ''The Merry Muses of Hibernia'', was planned but never completed. Gogarty's literary output during the forties and fifties is generally considered to be inferior to his earlier writings.<ref>Williams, p. 2</ref>
Gogarty suffered from heart complaints during the last few years of his life, and in September 1957 he collapsed in the street on his way to dinner. He died on 22 September 1957; his body was flown home to Ireland and buried in Cartron Church, Moyard, near Renvyle.
==Literary portrayal== [[File:Revolutionary Joyce Better Contrast.jpg|thumb|right|James Joyce]] A highly visible and distinctive [[Dublin]] character during his lifetime, Gogarty appears in a number of memoirs penned by his contemporaries, notably George Moore's ''Hail and Farewell'', where he goes both by his own name and by the pseudonym "Conan."<ref>O'Connor, pp. 51–52</ref> His most famous literary incarnation, however, is as [[Buck Mulligan]], the irrepressible roommate of [[Stephen Dedalus]] in James Joyce's ''Ulysses''. Mulligan quotes a number of songs and poems known to have been written by Gogarty,<ref>Carens, pp. 25–26</ref> the most famous of which, [[The Ballad of Japing Jesus|"The Song of the Cheerful (But Slightly Sarcastic) Jesus"]], was originally sent to Joyce as a belated Christmas peace offering after their quarrels of 1904.<ref>Ellmann, p. 214</ref> Other details, such as Mulligan's [[Hellenism (neoclassicism)|Hellenism]], his status as a medical student, his history of saving men from drowning, his friendship with George Moore, and the metrical arrangement of his full name (Malachi Roland St. John Mulligan) parallel Gogarty's biography. Due to his influence on Joyce (he is also sometimes cited as an inspiration for ''[[Dubliners]]'' character Ignatius Gallaher and ''[[Exiles (play)|Exiles]]'' antagonist Robert Hand), Gogarty's name often comes up in Joyce scholarship, though Gogarty's own editors and biographers have complained that these references are frequently inaccurate, owing to Gogarty-related errata in [[James Joyce (biography)|Richard Ellmann's ''James Joyce'']] and a tendency to conflate the real-life Gogarty with the fictional character of Buck Mulligan.<ref>Carens, pp. 10–21</ref>
It has also been suggested{{who|date=November 2012}} that the speaker of W. B. Yeats's poem ''High Talk'', "Malachi Stilt-Jack", is intended to be a representation of Gogarty.<ref>Carens, pp. 7–8</ref>
==Legacy== A pub in the [[Temple Bar, Dublin|Temple Bar]] district of Dublin is named after him, and an annual Oliver St. John Gogarty Literary Festival is held in the author's family home, now the Renvyle House Hotel in [[Connemara]]. A surgical ward in the descendant hospital of his workplace, the [[Tallaght Hospital|AMNCH]], now also bears his name.
==Books== *''Hyperthuleana'' (1916) [[File:Gogarty.JPG|thumb|right|The Oliver St. John Gogarty Pub in Dublin]] *''[[Blight (play)|Blight: The Tragedy of Dublin]]'' (1917) *''Secret Springs of Dublin Song'' (1918) *''The Ship and Other Poems'' (1918) *''A Serious Thing'' (1919) *''The Enchanted Trousers'' (1919) *''An Offering of Swans'' (1923) *''An Offering of Swans and Other Poems'' (1924) *''Wild Apples'' (three versions: 1928, 1929, 1930) *''Selected Poems'' (1933) *''[[As I Was Going Down Sackville Street]]'' (1937) *''Others to Adorn'' (1938) *''I Follow St. Patrick'' (1938) *''Elbow Room'' (two versions: 1939, 1942) *''Tumbling in the Hay'' (1939) *''Going Native'' (1940) *''Mad Grandeur'' (1941) *''Perennial'' (two versions: 1944, 1946) *''Mr. Petunia'' (1946) *''Mourning Became Mrs. Spendlove'' (1948) *''Rolling Down the Lea'' (1949) *''Intimations'' (1950) *''Collected Poems'' (1951) *''Unselected Poems'' (1954) *''It Isn't This Time of Year At All!: An Unpremeditated Autobiography'' (1954) *''Start From Somewhere Else'' (1955) *''A Weekend in the Middle of the Week'' (1958) *''The Poems & Plays of Oliver St. John Gogarty'' (containing rare and unpublished material, 2001)
==Sources== {{Reflist|30em}}
===Biography=== *{{cite book |title= Surpassing Wit |last= Carens |first= James |year= 1979 |publisher= Columbia University Press |location= New York |page= 22}} *{{cite book |title= James Joyce |last= Ellmann |first= Richard |year= 1982 |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= Oxford}} *{{cite book |title= Oliver St. John Gogarty: A Poet and His Times |last= O'Connor |first= Ulick |year= 1963 |publisher= Jonathan Cape |location= London}} *[[J. B. Lyons]], ''Oliver St. John Gogarty'' (1976, 1980)

<!--... Attention: THIS IS AN OUTLINE
part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to photography:
'''[[Photography]]''' – process of making [[image|pictures]] by the action of recording [[light]] patterns, reflected or emitted from objects, on a [[photosensitive]] medium or an [[image sensor]] through a timed [[Exposure (photography)|exposure]]. The process is done through [[Machine|mechanical]], [[Photochemistry|chemical]], or [[Optoelectronics|electronic]] devices known as [[camera]]s.
{{TOC limit|limit=2}} Meditative photography
== Forms of photography ==
=== By subject ===
* [[Architectural photography]] * [[Astrophotography]]
*[[Celebrity photography]] *[[Cloudscape photography]] *[[Environmental portrait]] *[[Erotic photography]] *[[Fashion photography]] *[[Fire photography]] *[[Fireworks photography]] *[[Food photography]] *[[Forensic photography]] *[[War photography]] *[[Wedding photography]] *[[Wildlife photography]] *[[Street photography]]
=== By technique ===
*[[Abstract photography]] *[[Aerial photography]] *[[Aviation photography]] *[[Digital photography]] *[[Endoscopy]] *[[Flash photography]] *[[High-speed photography]] *[[Time-lapse photography]]
=== By style ===
*[[Black and white photography]] *[[Candid photography]] *[[Conceptual photography]] *[[Conservation photography]] *[[Documentary photography]] *[[Fine-art photography]]
=== Unsorted ===
*[[Fundus photography]] *[[Geophotography]] *[[Glamour photography]] *[[Industrial photography]] *[[iPhoneography]] *[[Kirlian photography]] *[[Lifestyle photography]] *[[Lo-fi photography]] *[[Lomography]] *[[Long-exposure photography]] *[[Low-key photography]] *[[Macro photography]] *[[Medical photography]] *[[Monochrome photography]] *[[Narrative photography]] *[[Nature photography]] *[[Night photography]] *[[Nude photography]] *[[Old-time photography]] *[[Panoramic photography]] *[[Paparazzi]] *[[Photojournalism]] *[[Photomicroscopy]] *[[Portrait photography]] *[[Post-mortem photography]] *[[Senior portraits]] *[[Social photography]] *[[Social documentary photography]] *[[Still life photography]] *[[Stock photography]] *[[Straight photography]] *[[Subminiature photography]] *[[Travel photography]] *[[Ultraviolet photography]] *[[Underwater photography]] *[[Vernacular photography]]
==Photographic technology==
=== [[Camera]] ===
*[[Still camera]] *[[Toy camera]]
* [[View camera]]
=== Film ===
*[[Photographic film]] *[[Film base]] *[[Film format]] *[[Film holder]] *[[Film scanner]] *[[Film stock]]
=== Lens ===
* [[Photographic filter|Filter]] * [[Photographic lens]]
=== Accessories ===
*[[Flash (photography)|Flash]] *[[Tripod (photography)|Tripod]]
=== Projection ===
*[[Slide projector]]
== Photographic processing ==
[[Photographic processing]] * [[C-41 process]] * [[Cross processing]] * [[Photographic developer|Developer]] * [[Dye coupler]] * [[E-6 process]] * [[Photographic fixer|Fixer]] * [[Push processing]] *[[Photographic processing|Film developing]]
==Photographic techniques==
* [[Afocal photography]] * [[Bokeh]] * [[Contre-jour]] * [[Color photography]] * [[Cross processing]] * [[Cyanotype]] * [[Dodging and burning]] * [[Full-spectrum photography]] * [[Harris shutter]] * [[Kinetic photography]] * [[Kite aerial photography]] * [[High-dynamic-range imaging|High-dynamic-range imaging (HDR)]] * [[Holography]] * [[Light painting]] * [[Macro photography]] * [[Miniature faking]] * [[Monochrome photography]] * [[Motion blur]] * [[Night photography]] * [[Panoramic photography]] * [[Panning (camera)|Panning]] * [[Photogram]] * [[Photographic print toning]] * [[Photographic processing]] * [[Push printing]] * [[Rephotography]] * [[Rollout photography]] * [[Solarisation]] * [[Stereoscopy]] * [[Stopping down]] * [[Sun printing]] * [[Tilt–shift photography]] * [[Infrared photography]] * [[Ultraviolet photography]] * [[Time-lapse photography]]
== History of photography ==
[[History of photography]] * [[Timeline of photography technology]] * [[Camera obscura]] * [[Daguerreotype]] * [[Autochrome Lumière]] * [[Dufaycolor]] * [[Farm Security Administration]] * [[William Fox Talbot]]
==Photographic concepts== *[[Composition (visual arts)|Composition]] in [[visual arts]] **[[Rule of thirds]] **[[Angle of view|Field of view]] **[[Perspective (visual)]] *[[Image histogram]] *[[Exposure (photography)|Exposure]] *[[Negative (photography)|Negative]] *[[Focus (optics)|Focus]] **[[Autofocus]] **[[Depth of field]] *[[Photograph]] *[[Vignetting]] *[[Shutter speed]] *[[Aperture]] *[[F-number]]

== See also == {{Portal|Photography}} *[[Photography by indigenous peoples of the Americas]]
==External links== {{Sisterlinks|Photography}}
<!-- Please do not add links to photo galleries and photographer communities here, nor any site selling photography related items. Wikipedia is not a link farm. If in doubt, discuss a proposed link on the talk page before adding it here. --> * [http://www.floridamemory.com/OnlineClassroom/photographic-processes/index.cfm Daguerreotype to Digital: A Brief History of the Photographic Process] From the State Library & Archives of Florida. * [http://www.cycleback.com/photoguide/index.html Judging the authenticity of Photographs: 1800s to Today] Guide for collectors and historians * [http://www.borodulincollection.com/index_eng.html Rarities of the USSR photochronicles] Pioneers of Soviet Photography. * [http://www.smithsonianeducation.org/educators/lesson_plans/every_picture/index.html "Every Picture Has a Story"] - uses pictures from the Smithsonian's collections to show the development of the technology through the nineteenth century. * [http://www.photo-web.com.au/shadesoflight Shades of Light (Australian Photography 1839 - 1988)] the online version of the original Shades of Light published 1998, Gael Newton, National Gallery of Australia. * [http://www.illustratedphotography.net/basic-photography Illustrated Photography - Basic Photography] - The basics of photography explained in a series of articles. * [http://www.camera-obscura.org/ Camera Obscura] - digital library on the history photographic techniques
